transcript:
Therapist: Let's continue our discussion about the CBT model and how it applies to your experiences, Alex. You mentioned earlier that receiving negative feedback on your photography triggered thoughts of "I'm not good enough, and no one appreciates my work," which led to feelings of worthlessness and discouragement. This is a great example of how our thoughts can influence our emotions and behaviors.

Patient: I see what you mean. It's like a chain reaction – the situation triggers the thought, which then leads to the emotion.

Therapist: Exactly! In CBT, we call this the "cognitive model." It's the idea that our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are all interconnected. By becoming more aware of our thought patterns and learning to challenge and reframe them, we can start to shift our emotions and behaviors in a more positive direction.

Patient: That makes a lot of sense. I guess I've never really stopped to question whether my thoughts are actually true or not.

Therapist: That's very common. Many of us go through life accepting our thoughts as facts, without realizing that they might be distorted or biased. In CBT, we call these "cognitive distortions." Some common examples include all-or-nothing thinking, overgeneralization, and jumping to conclusions.

Patient: I definitely recognize some of those in myself. Like when I get a negative comment on my photography, I immediately jump to the conclusion that I'm not good enough and that no one appreciates my work.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Alex. The thought "I'm not good enough" is a cognitive distortion called "labeling." It's when we assign a global label to ourselves based on a single event or experience. Another distortion that might be at play here is "mental filter," where we focus exclusively on the negative aspects of a situation and filter out the positive.

Patient: Wow, I never realized how much my thoughts could be distorting reality. It's kind of eye-opening.

Therapist: It is! And the good news is that once we become aware of these distortions, we can start to challenge and reframe them. For example, instead of jumping to the conclusion that you're not good enough based on one negative comment, you could try to look at the situation more objectively. Maybe the person who left the comment was having a bad day, or perhaps they just have different tastes in photography.

Patient: That's true. I guess I tend to take things personally, even when they might not be about me at all.

Therapist: That's another great insight. Learning to separate ourselves from our thoughts and experiences can be really powerful. It allows us to see things more clearly and respond in a healthier, more balanced way.

Patient: I like the sound of that. It's just hard to know where to start sometimes.

Therapist: That's understandable. We'll work together to identify specific cognitive distortions that are contributing to your depression and practice challenging and reframing them. It takes practice, but over time, it can become second nature.

Patient: I'm willing to give it a try. I know I can't keep going on like this, feeling so down all the time.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that you're open to trying something new. Remember, change is possible, and you don't have to do it alone. We'll be working together every step of the way.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. That means a lot to me.
